that let's talk about why we're doing this why does key flow exist so it came out
of facing having faced a lot of the main challenges and building machine learning
applications one of the biggest challenges was moving from one environment to another so forklifting
code from local into dev into test and into production that path can be fraught
with error and what we needed was something that gave us portability so a way to package all those infrastructure
components together so that we could forklift our code from one place to another without actually changing
anything because there's a fundamental difference between running something locally on your laptop and running it in
a data center in production and another major challenge that we faced was this year complexity of machine learning
applications so the common perception is that when we think about our
applications we tend to think about the ml components as being sort of larger than everything else and more important
noticing usually reflect reality reality is that there are a lot of other very
important components as part of the application and before you can even create your models you need data there's
a lot involved in getting data ingesting it analyzing it cleaning it up exploring
it and separating out your training from your test set so you can extract your
features once you have your data and then you can build your models but once you have them you still need to validate
them you want to be doing some auditing versioning of them hopefully doing some
distributed training and doing that continuously as new data comes in those
models they live somewhere they live inside an application and that means you have a user interface that means you
have some business logic if you have users you're doing some load balancing and you need some serving infrastructure
that application has to live somewhere it lives inside a platform and for a
platform you need things like monitoring logging CI CD Solutions off all of the
normal things that go along with maintaining software so that's a lot more than just ml so we needed something that was more specific than just
supporting the ml components of the application so to solve the complexity
problem we needed some things that gave us composability so a way to create components that we could reuse common
things common patterns and templates that we could reuse throughout our applications and create logical groups a
maintaining such a complex system is a challenge because it's not always
straightforward to even identify errors some models we don't even have good ways
of identifying when there's things like bias that show up so if we can identify
errors can we recover from them and prevent them from happening in the future if we can fix those bugs how
quickly can we do that how quickly can we go through the development process in ml apps that's traditionally been very
difficult can we roll back to a version that didn't have the air all of these
challenges that are generally solved in the traditional software space are pretty big when it comes to ml apps so
composability helps us to shorten that development lifecycle so that we can iterate faster and fix things and
automate that process so capacity planning a lot of times in machine learning
applications you may not have necessarily have regular usage patterns
training has a much bigger footprint in general than serving and that sometimes look different based on when
new data arrives um but even when we have well defined usage patterns that
can spike we have users demand can spike at times and we want to be able to use our resources efficiently so that's why
we chose kubernetes because scalability is baked into the platform it's fundamental to it and then one of the
gke features that we really like is Auto provisioning which you'll see it's part of the lab so you'll get to see that in

pipelines command where we essentially just request Ram and GPUs and that turns

will give us a brand new GP with exactly as much as we need and the
cool thing about that is not just that we get it on demand but that once that job is finished and there's no more
demand for that resource the node disappears and it gets decommissioned so we're only paying for it for essentially
as long as our job is running so that's a cluster wide setting and that means
that any any resource request you send to the cluster will be you know within

about some of the main goal so you heard about all the challenges those are just a few there's many challenges but the
idea behind queue flow if I could sum it up in a single sentence would be to make it easy for everyone to develop deploy
and manage portable scalable ml everywhere and that everyone is important the idea is to make it more
approachable and easier so that not just data engineers and ml engineers are the
ones who can build applications so our three main goals we have portability we
want to be able to deploy across environments and forklift our code from develop into tests into prod and not
just the mo components but really the entire stack we want to take our entire application and move it easily from one
place to another the second major goal is scalability this answers your question about why we
chose kubernetes scalability is baked in but we use vanilla kubernetes api s and
so the idea is that if you have a kubernetes compliant system you can run queue flow on top of it but it's not
just about scalability in terms of nodes it's also it makes your application a
lot less complicated because for example networking you can call services by their name without having to know where
they're running that's why we love kubernetes the third major goal is composability is having this single
unified tool so common patterns patterns that are specific to ml applications and necessarily to anything else we want to
be able to reuse those components and pull them in pretty easily so not just
for the production version of it but that full product lifecycle from design to development to deployment and then

specialized hardware like GPUs and TP use what we'll be using today is a bunch
